docs.abstract: Google and Facebook are struggling to catch up with Twitch, a service that Amazon bought four years ago for $1.1 billion.
docs.snippet: Google and Facebook are struggling to catch up with Twitch, a service that Amazon bought four years ago for $1.1 billion.
docs.lead_paragraph: Late on a recent night, more than 600,000 people watched one of the most popular video game players, Tyler Blevins, engage in Fortnite Battle Royale with a celebrity guest: Drake.

headline.main: With Twitch, Amazon Tightens Grip on Live Streams of Video Games
headline.print_headline: Amazon Tightens Grip on Video Game Live Streaming

docs.abstract: The digital assistant confused a discussion about hardwood floors with several commands, in what Amazon called an “unlikely” string of events.
docs.snippet: The digital assistant confused a discussion about hardwood floors with several commands, in what Amazon called an “unlikely” string of events.
docs.lead_paragraph: They’re always listening. They’re on the internet. But what happens when digital assistants like Alexa go rogue? Could they share our private conversations without our consent? Privacy advocates have long warned this could happen, and now it has.

headline.main: Is Alexa Listening? Amazon Echo Sent Out Recording of Couple’s Conversation
headline.print_headline: Is Alexa Listening? Device Shared Recording of Couple’s Conversation

docs.abstract: Amazon’s chief executive sent out his annual shareholder letter this week. Our tech columnist recounts what stood out from it.
docs.snippet: Amazon’s chief executive sent out his annual shareholder letter this week. Our tech columnist recounts what stood out from it.
docs.lead_paragraph: Each week, Kevin Roose, technology columnist at The New York Times, discusses developments in the tech industry, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two. Want this newsletter in your inbox? Sign up here.

headline.main: Kevin’s Week in Tech: Jeff Bezos Reminds Tech Who’s Boss
headline.print_headline: Jeff Bezos Reminds Tech Who’s Boss

docs.abstract: Almost everyone had an opinion on the company’s reversal on a second headquarters in Queens.
docs.snippet: Almost everyone had an opinion on the company’s reversal on a second headquarters in Queens.
docs.lead_paragraph: [What you need to know to start the day: Get New York Today in your inbox.]

headline.main: What People Are Saying About Amazon’s Breakup With New York City
headline.print_headline: What People Are Saying About the Breakup

docs.abstract: Amazon’s pullout poses a challenge to one of the company’s bedrock beliefs: that being loved by customers is all that matters.
docs.snippet: Amazon’s pullout poses a challenge to one of the company’s bedrock beliefs: that being loved by customers is all that matters.
docs.lead_paragraph: Amazon’s surprise announcement on Thursday that it was canceling its planned expansion to a new corporate campus in New York was greeted with celebration by local activists and politicians who had opposed the deal, and frustration by local officials — and more than a few real estate agents in Queens — who had eagerly anticipated an influx of well-compensated tech workers.

headline.main: For Once, Amazon Loses a Popularity Contest
headline.print_headline: Amazon, Caught Flat-Footed, Chooses Fleeing Over Fighting

docs.abstract: Pressure applied by activists and many elected officials led to Amazon pulling out of Queens, but a political backlash may await them.
docs.snippet: Pressure applied by activists and many elected officials led to Amazon pulling out of Queens, but a political backlash may await them.
docs.lead_paragraph: [What you need to know to start the day: Get New York Today in your inbox.]

headline.main: Amazon’s Exit Forces a Reckoning for N.Y. Political Leaders
headline.print_headline: Stunning Loss for Cuomo and de Blasio Is Win for Left

docs.abstract: And it’s got a little bit of everything.
docs.snippet: And it’s got a little bit of everything.
docs.lead_paragraph: Gail Collins: Bret, in honor of Valentine’s Day, I’m going to give you the gift of deciding what current event we should start off with. Virginia? Jeff Bezos? Trump investigations? Supreme Court? Rapidly exploding population of Democratic presidential candidates?

byline.original: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens

docs.abstract: What kinds of companies will be the next so-called unicorns? A hint: Many of them won’t have much in common with Uber or Airbnb.
docs.snippet: What kinds of companies will be the next so-called unicorns? A hint: Many of them won’t have much in common with Uber or Airbnb.
docs.lead_paragraph: Hi. I’m Steve Lohr. I write about the technology industry, from the old titans like IBM to start-ups working on the future of artificial intelligence.

headline.main: The Week in Tech: A Break From Consumer Tech
headline.print_headline: The New Breed of Unicorn, and Other Updates

docs.abstract: Virginia can teach New York a few things about how to make a deal that actually works.
docs.snippet: Virginia can teach New York a few things about how to make a deal that actually works.
docs.lead_paragraph: When Amazon abandoned its plans to build a new headquarters in New York, the foes of corporate greed declared victory. Yet, should all the outrage be aimed at Amazon?

headline.main: A Better Way to Attract Amazon’s Jobs
